where_to_read: This is gonna be a long ride

reviews.review_text: This is one of the best memoirs / historical books I have read in some time. Just majestic in scope and beautifully written. It discusses an area of the world (Libya) of which I knew very little but now I know a lot more. I am very grateful that the author wrote this. I feel like a better person having read it. Bravo.

I liked the idea of this book and found the details about Libya past and present (a country about which I do not have a depth of knowledge) to be fascinating.  What I did not like, however, was the arrogance and egocentrism of the author, who tried desperately to situate himself at the centre of every single situation. He was a much better writer when he stuck to relaying facts, but the relentless self promotion and self flagellation wore me down. I read the book to the end because I rarely abandon a book midway through, but I found myself getting increasingly annoyed as time went on. I was relieved to have finished it.

I did not like the book at all. Is was disappointing from beginning to end, just another personal account of some happening the same of which we are now reading about in every daily newspaper by the page full. And nobody either can or will do anything about all the violence happening in the middle-east countries today.  There is  no conclusion, there is no moral. the writer shows himself as week and inactive whereas his brother seems to do all the research on the father's whereabouts.Th book is not even written well. I don't need any more of this type of book, simply an offloading of some personal feelings. I am not a psychoanalyst.
it's a good book, the writer is well informed on many events both historical and actual!!
This book is a testament to both the tenacity of life and the unforgiving nature of those that are no longer humanists. They are feral hunters and destroyers of mindfulness.
Heartbreaking account of author's mission to make sense of his father's kidnapping.  Very well written and an important read.
Beautifully written giving  very personal memories and places universal meaning.

A moving story vividly told, but hard to follow. Too many flashbacks and jumps in time and place. Same ingredients more intelligently organized would have been a really top notch experience. A little more thought for the reader?

title: The Return: Fathers, Sons and the Land in Between

summary:
WINNER OF THE PULITZER PRIZE 

The acclaimed memoir about fathers and sons, a legacy of loss, and, ultimately, healing--one of The New York Times Book Review's ten best books of the year.

When Hisham Matar was a nineteen-year-old university student in England, his father went missing under mysterious circumstances. Hisham would never see him again, but he never gave up hope that his father might still be alive. Twenty-two years later, he returned to his native Libya in search of the truth behind his father's disappearance. The Return is the story of what he found there. 
The Pulitzer Prize citation hailed The Return as "a first-person elegy for home and father." 

Transforming his personal quest for answers into a brilliantly told universal tale of hope and resilience, Matar has given us an unforgettable work with a powerful human question at its core: How does one go on living in the face of unthinkable loss?
story_arc: Opens with good fortunes, but doomed to fail
